name: Amy Carmichael
summary: Irish Christian missionary in India who served for 55 years without furlough. She rescued hundreds of children from temple prostitution and founded the Dohnavur Fellowship.

biography.title: Early Life in Ireland
biography.content: Amy Beatrice Carmichael was born on 16 December 1867 in the village of Millisle, County Down, Ireland. She was the eldest of seven children in a devout Presbyterian family.

biography.title: Call to Service
biography.content: At age 20, Amy felt called to missionary service after hearing Hudson Taylor speak. She first served briefly in Japan before finding her life's work in India.

biography.title: Rescue Work in India
biography.content: In 1901, Amy rescued her first child from temple prostitution. This began her lifelong work of rescuing children, particularly girls, from exploitation and abuse.

biography.title: Dohnavur Fellowship
biography.content: Amy established the Dohnavur Fellowship, a community that became home to over 900 rescued children. The fellowship operated schools, hospitals, and provided family-style care.

timeline.description: Amy Carmichael born in Millisle, County Down
Started work among mill girls in Belfast
First missionary assignment in Japan (15 months)
Began work in South India, never to return home
Rescued Preena, a 7-year-old girl from temple prostitution
Founded the Dohnavur Fellowship in Tamil Nadu
Fell into a pit, injuring her back and becoming bedridden
Passed away after 55 years of service in India
